node.text: The fast-spreading #deltavariant is raising fresh health concerns even in places where Covid vaccination rates are high. Senior pharmaceuticals analyst Sam Fazeli is here to tell you what you need to know.

node.title: Your Biggest Delta Variant Questions Answered

node.text:
"Donald Trump upended the American presidency after stepping away from the company that made him rich and famous. Four years later, returning to his empire after losing the White House, what he finds may upend him," write Sophie Alexander and Max Abelson.

"Three quarters of Trump's net worth is tied up in urban real estate. And urban real estate has been hammered by Covid-19," Tim O'Brien tells @quicktake's Tim Stenovec.

The former president's net worth is down to $2.3 billion from $3 billion in 2016. The pandemic he promised would disappear is walloping his company, and the riot that got him impeached for a second time is wounding his brand.

Check out "Trump’s Ailing Empire" on bloomberg.com/graphics to see just how deep in peril he really is.

node.text:
👻 Snap Inc. is rolling out a new tool for its Snapchat app to feature popular videos, called Spotlight, and said it will pay out $1 million a day to creators of the top-performing posts. How good of a deal is that?

🤳🏻 "The more remarkable thing about Snap is that it wasn't offering these sort of incentives to people to create good content previously."

Alex Webb joined @quicktake's Tim Steno to explain why Snap decided to compensate viral creators.

#snapchat #influencer #app #creators #snap

node.title: Snapchat to Pay $1 Million a Day to Creators

node.text:
It’s been 20 months since a pair of fatal crashes forced regulators around the globe to ground the once top-selling jet. The FAA finally approved the Max to resume commercial flights today, which will allow Boeing to make money off the roughly 450 Max jets it has built but not yet delivered.

After the longest grounding of an aircraft in modern U.S. history, it’s reasonable to ask whether the plane is safe. Bloomberg Opinion columnists Chris Bryant and Brooke Sutherland teamed up to discuss the future of the Max, and whether or not they'd be willing to board one.

#Boeing #Boeing737 #737max #airplane #aircraft #airline #southwest #americanair #flight #pandemic #livestream #video #igtv #travel

node.title: Boeing’s 737 Max Is Back. Are You Willing to Board?

node.text:
Frank Barry didn’t ask a soul about Donald Trump or Joe Biden on his @looking4lincoln trip. For the two months he spent crossing the country along the Lincoln Highway by Winnebago, talking with Americans and hoping to reach San Francisco by Election Day, he never brought up the campaign. Sometimes he knew how people felt — occasionally they would say, though usually not. But it didn’t matter. He wasn’t running a focus group. He was trying to catch glimpses of a more enduring spirit, the kind that has transcended parties and generations, the kind that lives, as Lincoln said, in the better angels of our nature. And maybe those glimpses could help us see more of ourselves in each other, and in the land we share.

#lincolnhighway #travel #rv #roadtrip #winnebago #highway #ontheroad #interview #video

node.title: The End of the Lincoln Highway

node.text:
“It was really impossible not to feel the immediacy, the urgency of climate change on this leg of the trip.”

Frank Barry stops in #Iowa and #Colorado, continuing his journey across the U.S. along the Lincoln Highway.

Video by @quicktake, footage by @looking4lincoln.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 16, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, child, people sitting and text that says 'Young Afghans' dreamso better life are evaporating BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
As the Taliban entered Kabul on Sunday, university lecturers gathered their female students for some final goodbyes. Telling the shocked young women “we may not meet again,” the lecturers, along with everyone else, were evacuated, and the universities, along with schools, offices and shops, were shuttered. 

Ruth Pollard spoke by phone with Aisha Khurram, one of those students whose academic dreams have been cut short. There are thousands more like her. The 22-year-old is in the final semester of her international relations degree at Kabul University. With just two months left, she says, “now it seems I will never graduate.”

It’s not just young women. In the tried and true playbook of militia all over the world, young men are pressured to join their ranks, their dreams of a better future evaporating with those of their sisters.

But despite the very real risk, many Afghans are continuing to speak out. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

#afghanistan #kabul

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 15, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, car and text that says 'You won't see TeslasinIndia India Teslas anytimesoon BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Elon Musk is right about one thing: India’s protectionism will make it hard for Tesla or any other automaker to build there. 

The country wants to get on the electric vehicle bandwagon, and is introducing China-style policies to pursue its green ambitions. There’s a wrinkle: its age-old, protectionist instincts, which have kept out international auto companies for decades, writes Anjani Trivedi. 

Many other parts of the world are embracing EV policies to meet emissions goals, but the administration of Prime Minister Narendra Modi has had a single-minded focus on its Make in India campaign. It's an effort to get its industrial manufacturing sector up and running.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Inflation for U.S. college tuition & fees has dropped Year-on-Year Price Increase of U.S. CPI College Tuition & Fees NSA (%) 15 10 1981 1990 2000 abor Statistics, Bloomberg 2010 2020 BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
🚨You already know the headlines: Inflation is here. But how bad is it?

After three months of being blindsided by inflation numbers far higher than forecast, we should be relieved to see that July’s was bang in line with average expectations, writes John Authers.

The persistent rise in college tuition fees, putting higher education further and further out of the reach of many Americans, has been a quiet, ongoing scandal. But colleges are having difficulty dealing with the pandemic, and many are discounting to try to fill campuses next month.

As a result, inflation in this huge part of the household budget (for anyone who has to pay it) has dropped to only 0.2%, its lowest since the series began 40 years ago.

One of the few benefits of the inflation scare of the last few months is that we are all far more familiar with the ingredients that go into the Bureau of Labor Statistics’ consumer price sausage. Tap the link in our bio for Authers's swift and impartial guided tour of said sausage.

#inflation #college #tuition #prices #cpi #labor #charts #data

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 15, 2021. May be an image of 3 people and text that says 'Warren Buffett isn't alone Big Tech is sitting ona pile of cash, too'.

node.text:
💸🚀 Jeff Bezos, since stepping away from Amazon, has become the latest billionaire to head to space. Meanwhile, Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg is eyeing life in the metaverse. But don’t expect to see Warren Buffett riding on the next rocket ship for his 91st birthday this month, writes Tara Lachapelle.

Unlike some of his ultra-wealthy peers, Buffett still prefers the nuts-and-bolts businesses of Planet Earth, such as keeping people’s lights on and delivering goods by freight train.

"With Buffett hoarding more than $100 billion of cash at Berkshire the last few years, the perception is that the investing icon has lost his touch in a technology-driven economy that would seem to be full of investment opportunities," Lachapelle writes.

But even as Buffett is criticized for that cash stockpile, it actually puts him in quite good company. Amazon — now led by CEO Andy Jassy — and Zuckerberg’s Facebook are each sitting on a heap of cash, too, as are Tim Cook at Apple, Sundar Pichai at Google’s parent Alphabet and Satya Nadella at Microsoft. Other than Berkshire, these are the most cash-rich companies in America and the most valuable.

Can these CEOs spend their cash without regulators impeding them? Tap the link in our bio to find out.

#buffett #zuckerberg #bezos #ceo #cash #apple #facebook #berkshirehathaway #amazon

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 15, 2021. May be an image of text that says '23% of Brits are unwilling to make any changes to help the climate If you had to do one of the following to reduce Britain's carbon emissions, which would it be? Never drive a petrol, diesel car Not be willing to do any of these 29% See overseas travel price substantially increase 23 See animal products prices substantially increase 20 13 Don't know 13 See domestic heating price substantially increase 2 Note: Figures don't add upt to 100%d duet March 31 YouGov survey for Sky BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Boris Johnson is facing a challenge: Getting the U.K. to net zero carbon emissions by 2050.

That's hard enough in the first place, but Jonathan Ford explains that Johnson is facing another challenge: A need to connect with a public that, while appreciative of the seriousness of the climate problem, does not yet see burdens on itself as part of the answer. 

A recent YouGov poll offered people a choice of four things they would be prepared to give up to curb carbon emissions. Almost a quarter were unwilling to accept any changes at all.

So how to sell the mission? Tap the link in our bio to read more.

#climatechange #netzero #borisjohnson

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 14, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says 'Disney's $5,000 Star Wars hotel starts new era of luxury travel ക BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
We’re due for a new era of high-end consumption. A $5,000 stay at an experiential Star Wars hotel is just the beginning, writes Conor Sen. 

Scheduled to open in 2022, Star Wars: Galactic Starcruiser will take two adults on a two-day “space voyage." 

To get a sense of people’s capacity to pay for luxury goods and experiences, consider aggregate household net worth divided by the number of U.S. households. Over the past 30 years, the net worth of the average American household has increased from $232,000 to $1.028 million.

These types of mega-luxury experiences aren't for everyone, but don't be surprised if we look back on this Star Wars hotel as the beginning of a new generation of luxury experiential travel.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion in Port Everglades. May be an image of outdoors and text that says 'U.S. Coast Guard dropped The. off 60,000 poundso cocaine in Florida'.

node.text:
At a Florida port, the U.S. Coast Guard drops off $1.4 billion worth of cocaine and marijuana seized in the Caribbean and Eastern Pacific.

The haul, the fruit of nearly 30 incidents and boarding operations by the U.S., Canada and the Netherlands, contains nearly 60,000 pounds of cocaine alone.

No, it’s not a reboot of “Miami Vice” — it happened last week: Huge shipments of drugs are being captured at sea on their way to the U.S. and Europe.

These are eye-popping numbers, even to those who have been involved in interdiction operations for decades. What is driving the trend toward huge shipments of narcotics, and how will U.S. authorities cope with it?

Tap the link in our bio to learn what former U.S. Navy admiral James Stavridis has to say about the drug war at sea.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Bloomberg Opinion on August 14, 2021 tagging @amandalittletrip. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Winston Churchill wanted lab-grown meat in 1931. 90 years ater it'sareality- oody wants to eat BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
In 1931, Winston Churchill wrote: "We shall escape the absurdity of growing a whole chicken in order to eat the breast or wing, by growing these parts separately under a suitable medium.”

Cell-cultured meat isn’t newfangled technology at all, writes @amandalittletrip: "Scientists have been growing animal tissues for decades for medical applications, such as life-saving heart valves."

And long before medical experts were doing this work, prominent public figures like Churchill had recognized the inherent inefficiency of industrial live-animal farming for meat production.

Tap the link in our bio to learn all about why lab-grown meat has enormous potential to become the foundation of a humane, climate-smart future protein supply.

#meat #history #churchill #labmeat #science #climate

node.text:
Raise your hand if you’re feeling emotionally exhausted right now. ✋ 

The stress of the dire events afflicting the world combined with physical isolation has no doubt had a subtle but unavoidable toll, writes Noah Smith. From Covid-19 to protests to the divisive presidential election, Americans might actually have become more resilient amid these challenges.

Most surveys generally say Americans are a little less happy than they used to be. The General Social Survey finds that happiness peaked at 2.257 on a scale of 1 to 3 in the year 1993, but by 2018 had fallen to 2.178. The recent dip is cause for worry. 

Attention is focused on the mental health consequences of Covid-19, but it’s the longer-term rise in U.S. unhappiness that should worry us more. Whatever was afflicting Americans’ mental health before Covid is likely to remain a problem.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 13, 2021. May be an image of 3 people, people standing and text that says 'Here's why President Xi Jinping wants cheaper weddings for China BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
💍 The Chinese government says many wedding customs — including "bride prices" and groom hazing — are now officially frowned upon. Will anyone listen? 

In Chongqing, one of China’s biggest cities, engaged couples will soon be eligible for a government-sponsored group wedding. The goal of the reform is to eliminate costs and customs that are contributing to China’s declining marriage and birth rates, writes Adam Minter. 

Officials hope the reforms will help prevent a looming population decline. It’s a risky bet. Rather than produce a baby boom, it’s more likely to produce resentment. 

Click the link in our bio to read the full column.

node.text:
🚨Calling all math fanatics: Today is the last "true" Fibonacci Day of the century.

August 13, 2021 is perfectly in line with Leonardo Fibonacci De Pisa's famous mathematical concept: the Fibonacci sequence.

The series of numbers starts with 1 and 1, and each number after is found by adding the two previous numbers. So 1 + 1 = 2, 1 + 2 = 3, 2 +3 = 5 and so on.

That's why today is so special, explains Scott Duke Kominers: 8-13-21 will be the *last* date that corresponds with the sequence until a century from now.

Crazy, right?

For more puzzling math facts and riddles, check out the latest Kominers’s Conundrums, link in bio.

#fibonacci #fibonaccispiral #fibonaccisequence #math #history

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 13, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'AnAMC GameStop collab makes total sense today universe BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Look, if you run a meme-stock company, you have to announce earnings four times a year, and then you will probably want to do an earnings call. If, on that earnings call, you take questions from your enthusiastic individual shareholders, (1) the questions will be insane, (2) your answers will be insane, (3) the shareholders will love it and (4) the stock will go up.

AMC did this, and got asked this: "Will AMC consider partnering with GameStop to offer more theater experiences via local and national gaming competitions?"

And its CEO Adam M. Aron replied with this: "I don't even think I can count the number of times people have asked me if we could partner with GameStop. We're certainly willing to do so."

Yes, right! Put the GameStop in the AMC! Drive there in a Tesla that you rented at a Hertz! Pay for your tickets with Dogecoin! Cram the whole thing into a rocket ship and send it to Mars! This is how finance works now; the goal is to say as many meme-trade buzzwords as possible because that is what makes stocks go up. That’s why you do a call like this, writes Matt Levine.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about AMC's wild ride.
